title: NSW declares protest ban for 14 days
description: NSW Police Commissioner Mal Lanyon has banned protests in Sydney for 14 days.  This comes after gun and protest reforms were passed by the NSW parliament on Wednesday.  The laws grant the police commissioner the power to ban protests for up to three months following the declaration of a terror incident.

title: ‘Very narrow’: Two-week ban on protests in NSW
description: NSW Shadow Police Minister Paul Toole discusses the time limitation on the ban of protests and public assemblies.  “These powers can only be used up to a period of three months,” Mr Toole told Sky News Australia.  “So there has to be a terrorist attack, here in NSW, before these powers can actually be applied.  “If you look at the last 11 years, we've only actually seen two terrorist incidents.  “We are very narrow with the laws that are actually being applied.”

title: The government has been ‘too slow’ to act on protests
description: NSW Shadow Police Minister Paul Toole reflects on the rise of Sydney protests, including the October 7 protests in Sydney, which got broadcast “around the world”.  “We became the laughing stock of the world,” Mr Toole told Sky News Australia.  “We've been calling on the government to do something about this now for over two and a half years.  “When you see a protest every few days or every weekend, that is a targeted campaign, that is a movement.  “The government has been too slow.” ​

title: NSW government cracks down on protests ‘two and a half years’ later
description: NSW Shadow Police Minister Paul Toole comments on the protests, held “every weekend” in Sydney since October 7.  “Hyde Park has been shut down for the last two and a half years because of a protest taking place,” Mr Toole told Sky News Australia.  “That actually sees police resources being diverted … we've got traffic control, emergency services.  “There has to be a point in time where taxpayers don't continuously foot the bill.”

title: ‘An attack on law-abiding citizens’: New gun laws draw criticism
description: NSW Shadow Police Minister Paul Toole claims “people are angry” with the new gun law reforms.  “These reforms were an attack on law-abiding citizens here in NSW,” Mr Toole told Sky News Australia.  “We've got farmers, landholders, sporting shooters who use firearms for all different purposes.”

title: ‘Light to overcome darkness’: Catholic Church delivers Christmas message
description: The Archbishop of Sydney Anthony Fisher has delivered his Christmas message, shining light in the darkness, following the Bondi terrorist attack.  “As many in our city grieve this Christmas, let us declare boldly: the light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it,” Mr Fisher said.  “In a season where both Jews and Christians celebrate light and hope, we've been confronted with profound evil.”

title: Astronauts wish the world a happy Christmas
description: Astronauts on the International Space Station have wished everyone a happy Christmas.  Last month, the International Space Station commemorated 25 years in orbit.  Seven astronauts are aboard Expedition 74, which was launched 17 days ago.  They'll stay in orbit until July.

title: Former Labor senator Nick Bolkus dies aged 75
description: Former Labor cabinet minister Nick Bolkus has died at age 75.  From 1980 until 2005, Mr Bolkus was a senator for South Australia.  During the Hawke and Keating administrations, he held various ministerial and assistant ministerial positions in addition to serving as immigration and ethnic affairs minister from 1993 to 1996.

title: Emergency warnings issued for out-of-control fires in WA
description: Emergency warnings have been issued for fires in Western Australia.  Residents in the town of Boddington, south-east of Perth, have been told to evacuate as firefighters battle an out-of-control bushfire on Christmas Day.  Another warning in Cowalla has been issued for a separate blaze, which has caused power cuts to more than 2000 nearby homes.

title: ‘Inflation ticked up’: RBA expected to raise cash rate next year
description: Deakin University Economist Dr Nataliya Ilyushina expects the RBA to raise the cash rate next year, potentially in the “second or third meeting”.  “Just at the end of the year inflation ticked up again to 3.8 per cent, leaving us in doubt about what to expect ahead,” Ms Ilyushina told Sky News Australia.  “RBA is taking very prudent and weighted steps … probably shouldn't expect any rate cuts next year at all.”

title: Australians exposed to the ‘harsh truth’ behind soaring energy prices
description: Deakin University Economist Dr Nataliya Ilyushina discusses the increase in Australians' energy bills, which are impacting inflation and the cost-of-living crisis.  “Electricity prices grew by 36 per cent in a year, which is the main driver of this last inflation spike,” Ms Ilyushina told Sky News Australia.  “RBA would have been aware that low inflation was driven by the electricity rebate, and as soon as that was taken off, we were exposed to this harsh truth about the energy prices.”

title: ‘Smarter not harder’: Australians advised to embrace AI
description: Deakin University Economist Dr Nataliya advises Australians to start embracing artificial intelligence.  “We're facing the fact that AI is here to stay and help us to work,” Ms Ilyushina told Sky News Australia.  “Smarter, not harder.”

title: Pope Leo delivers his midday Christmas sermon
description: Pope Leo XIV delivers his midday Christmas sermon at the Vatican.  “In the darkness of the light, the true light, which enlightens everyone, is coming into the world,”  Pope Leo XIV said.  “Let us not allow ourselves to be overcome by indifference toward those who suffer, for God is not indifferent to our distress.”

title: Pope Leo marks his first Christmas of ‘peace' at the Vatican
description: Pope Leo XIV addresses crowds at the Vatican to “open their hearts” on Christmas Day, a day of “peace”.  “In him [Jesus], every wound is healed, and every heart finds rest and peace,” Pope Leo XIV said.  “The Lord’s birth is the birth of peace.  “To all of you, I offer heartfelt good wishes for a peaceful and holy Christmas.”

title: Victoria water levels fell 13.2 per cent in 2025
description: Victoria is experiencing the fastest decline in water levels since the Millennium Drought.  In the last 12 months, water storage has decreased by 13.2 per cent.  According to Melbourne Water, that amount would need to decrease to 150 litres per person to guarantee avoiding water restrictions.
